AUDIENCE

This section is for SB/SE excise tax managers (excise managers), excise tax revenue agents (RAs) and fuel compliance agents (FCAs)(excise examiners), and personnel at the Cincinnati and Ogden campuses who process excise tax returns (returns), excise tax refunds (refunds) and excise tax claims (claims).

) Purpose - This IRM section provides general guidelines and report writing cedures for excise managers, excise examiners and personnel at the Scope and Cincinnati and Ogden campuses who process claims for refund or credit. Excise examiners located in ﬁeld offices examine claims. (

) Audience - The audience of this IRM section includes the Director, Specialty Examination, Chief, Estate & Gift and Excise Tax Examination, territory managers, excise managers and excise examiners. (

) Policy Owner - The Director Examination - Specialty Policy is responsible for the administration, procedures and updates related to the technical guidance and information processing steps and methods speciﬁc to claims. (
) Program Owner - The Director, Specialty Examination owns Excise Tax. (

) Primary Stakeholders - Other areas that follow these policies and include Appeals, Agency-Wide Shared Services, Counsel, SB/SE Large Business and International and Tax Exempt and Government Entities. (
) Program Goals - The processes and procedures provided in this IRM are sistent with the objectives or goals for Excise Tax - Examination that are addressed in IRM
, Organization and Staffing, Small Business Self/Employed (SB/SE), Excise Tax Examination. (
) This IRM section provides the intended audience the policies and procedures for claims. (

, which provides the nation’s taxpayers with a better understanding of their rights and helps reinforce the fairness of the tax system. In
, Congress charged the missioner with ensuring IRS employees are familiar with and act in with taxpayer rights as afforded by IRC

), Execution of duties in cordance with taxpayer rights. IRS employees must be informed about tax- payer rights and be conscientious in the performance of their duties to respect and communicate effectively those rights that may aid in reducing payer burdens. This section provides general guidelines and procedures for claims. A claim is either a “formal” or an “informal” request. • Formal claims are ﬁled on any of the forms listed under IRM Claim Form Types. • An “informal” claim is a request for a refund submitted by the either on a non-standard form (written request) or by some other so long as the required claim elements are identiﬁed. An informal must have a written component apprising the Service a refund is and describe the legal and factual basis for the refund, so the may investigate the claim. Refer to IRM
, Informal Claims, and IRM

, Claims, for additional information. Claims include: • Claims for credit. • Claims for refund. • Requests for abatement, which are requests for reduction of tax, and interest that has not been paid. Protective claims are formal claims or amended returns for credit or normally based on expected changes in a: • Current regulation. • Pending legislation. • Current litigation. Protective claims are ﬁled to protect the claimant’s right to recover tax the Treasury before the expiration of the statute of limitations (SOL). A identifying a pending court case or decision should be considered a claim. Refer to IRM
, Protective Claims, for additional An examination includes analysis of all claims and Form

• Formal claims are ﬁled on any of the forms listed under IRM

, Claim Form Types. • An “informal” claim is a request for a refund submitted by the taxpayer either on a non-standard form (written request) or by some other means so long as the required claim elements are identiﬁed. An informal claim must have a written component apprising the Service a refund is sought and describe the legal and factual basis for the refund, so the Service may investigate the claim.
